Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Chromosome inversions and reproductive isolation in an avian hybrid zone
Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientists' understanding of the way in which two species arise from a common ancestor has greatly improved since the time of Darwin. We now know that the most common way species form is when different populations become geographically separated from each other and begin to genetically diverge. We also know that this process can take millions of years. But at any time, during the process of splitting, populations may come back into contact and form a narrow zone of contact where individuals from one group mate with individuals from the other group (a hybrid zone). While hybridization generally leads to a slowdown in the rate at which new species form because their genomes are no longer separate, several mechanisms have been identified whereby hybridization can actually promote divergence. This project focuses on the evolution of chromosome inversions, rearrangements to the structure of the genome that act as genetic barriers between young species that share some gene exchange in narrow hybrid zones. This information is critical to understanding the natural consequences of geographic divergence, periodic gene exchange, speciation, and the resulting biodiversity that is present on Earth. Education-related public outreach efforts at the Field Museum of Natural History, where the research takes place, will involve Chicago area high school and undergraduate students.

These researchers study a hybrid zone between subspecies of the long-tailed finch (Poephila acuticauda). Subspecies differ in beak color (yellow vs. red) and hybridize across a narrow contact zone in northern Australia. Genetic differences between subspecies are largely restricted to one chromosome. Several large chromosome inversions are on the same chromosome. The researchers will examine the genomes of individual birds from across the hybrid zone to identify the genes encoding a reproductive isolating trait: beak color.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on a hybrid zone located in northern Australia between subspecies of the long-tailed finch (Poephila acuticauda) in order to examine the evolution of chromosome inversions, rearrangements to the structure of the genome that can act as genetic barriers between incipient species. Chromosome inversions are a frequently found class of structural mutation both as variants within species and as fixed differences between species. However, despite their ubiquity across the plant and animal kingdoms, the forces underlying their evolution has remained in many ways mysterious since they were first described nearly 100 years ago. One recent theoretical model, however, predicts that chromosome inversions are likely to be present in hybrid zones, areas where incipient species meet, mate, and produce hybrid offspring; as they are strongly favored in this context due to their ability to keep sets of differentially adapted genes together despite the otherwise homogenizing influence of hybridization. Through the support of this NSF doctoral dissertation improvement grant, we evaluated support for the predictions of this model with an avian hybrid zone where chromosome inversions are known to occur.

 

The researchers made two principal discoveries over the course of this project. First, there are two non-overlapping north-south hybrid zones between subspecies of the long-tailed finch. The first of which, located just west of the Northern Territory town of Katherine, constitutes a morphological zone of admixture where beak color, the defining physical trait difference between subspecies, is highly variable and confined to an area 150km in width. The second of which, located around the Western Australian town of Kununurra, is a genetic zone of admixture 120km in width. The centers of these two hybrid zones, one morphological and one genetic, are displaced by approximately 350km. These findings were the result of a field expedition in 2015 to measure geographic variation in beak color, across a 1500km east-west transect of the range of the long-tailed finch, and took beak color measurements and blood samples for genetic analysis from nearly 750 individuals. The researchers sequenced a reduced representation of the whole genome for nearly 300 long-tailed finch individuals, spanning the width of their range but with special attention to populations in the center with greater beak color variation, in order to evaluate the geographic structure of genetic variation.

 

With regard to the role of chromosome inversions, the researchers observed that the narrow genetic hybrid zone between long-tailed finch subspecies was due primarily to the rapid turnover of genetic content on a single chromosome known to have inversion variation in the species: the Z chromosome. The Z chromosome, an avian sex chromosome analogous to the mammalian X chromosome, is commonly elevated in differentiation in hybrid zones and is also frequently home to chromosome inversions. The researchers observe rapid turnover and tight linkage between genetic variation within the narrow hybrid zone consistent with chromosome inversion differences between subspecies. This finding is in line with theoretical expectations for inversions to be favored in hybrid zones, due to their ability to keep sets of differentially adapted genes together, and is one of the first empirical examples of this phenomenon in birds. Moreover, the displacement of the genetic and morphological hybrid zones suggests that this trait may not be involved in reproductive isolation between subspecies – in contradiction to the establishment of the two long-tailed finch subspecies based on this trait.
